title: Physical pendulums - two-sphere pendulum diff eqn

content.question: A physical pendulum is made from two small spheres attached to a stiff wire of negligible mass and length <math alttext="L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure. One sphere has mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and is at the bottom end of the wire, and the other sphere has mass <math alttext="2 uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and is at the midpoint of the wire. If the pendulum makes small-angle oscillations, which of the following differential equations describes the pendulum’s motion? The pendulum angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math> is taken relative to the vertical.

choices.label: <math alttext="the second derivative of theta with respect to t equals the negative fraction g over L sub 0, end fraction, theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mi>θ</mi></math>

<math alttext="the second derivative of theta with respect to t equals, negative, open parenthesis, three halves, close parenthesis, the fraction g over L sub 0, end fraction, theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mi>θ</mi></math>

<math alttext="the second derivative of theta with respect to t equals, negative, open parenthesis, four thirds, close parenthesis, the fraction g over L sub 0, end fraction, theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mi>θ</mi></math>

<math alttext="the second derivative of theta with respect to t equals, negative, open parenthesis, six fifths, close parenthesis, the fraction g over L sub 0, end fraction, theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mi>θ</mi></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the second derivative of theta with respect to t equals, negative, open parenthesis, four thirds, close parenthesis, the fraction g over L sub 0, end fraction, theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mi>θ</mi></math>

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
